qas.question: When was the Gregorian Calendar introduced?
What calendar was used in the reform to create the Gregorian calendar?
What holiday was the inducement to revise the Julian calendar?
When did the First Council of Nicaea rule that Easter be celebrated by all Christians?
What was the Julian calendar a reform of?
What calendar was started in the fifteenth century?
Which Pope started the Julian calendar?
What holiday led to the revision of the Gregorian calendar
Who suggested that all Christians celebrate Easter on the same day during the third century?

context: <b5_0><b6_0>The Gregorian calendar<b6_0/><b5_0/> was a reform of the <a2_0>Julian calendar<a2_0/> instituted in <a1_0>1582<a1_0/> by <a0_0><b7_0>Pope Gregory XIII<b7_0/><a0_0/>, after whom the calendar was named, by papal bull Inter gravissimas dated 24 February 1582. The motivation for the adjustment was to bring the date for the celebration of <a3_0><b8_0>Easter<b8_0/><a3_0/> to the time of year in which it was celebrated when it was introduced by the early Church. Although a recommendation of <b9_0>the First Council of Nicaea<b9_0/> in 325 specified that all Christians should celebrate Easter <a4_0>on the same day<a4_0/>, it took almost five centuries before virtually all Christians achieved that objective by adopting the rules of the Church of Alexandria (see Easter for the issues which arose).
